description: From Middle English parlai (“speech, parley”), from Old French parler (“to talk; to speak”), from Late Latin parabolō, from Latin parabola (“comparison”), from Ancient Greek παραβολή (parabolḗ), from παρά (pará, “beside”) with βολή (bolḗ, “throwing”). Doublet of palaver.

entries.meaning: A conference, especially one between enemies.
examples: Without further parley Garland rode off up the hog's-back and the sheriff rode off down it [...]

verbs.description: parley (third-person singular simple present parleys, present participle parleying, simple past and past participle parleyed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have a discussion, especially one between enemies.
examples: [...] at day break we found the villaine, who, loath to parlee in fire and ſhot, fled amaine and left us [...]
